let somebody/something ↔ down.translati: to not do something that someone trusts or expects you to do
let the side down British English (=disappoint a group of people that you belong to)
She had been let down badly in the past.
The worst feeling is having let our fans down.
to make someone or something less successful or effective
McKenzie’s judgement rarely lets him down.
to move something or someone to a lower position
Let down a rope so that I can climb up.
Carefully, she let herself down into the water.
to relax and enjoy yourself, especially after working hard
Visitors young and old let their hair down and enjoyed the show.
to relax and stop worrying about what might happen or what someone might find out about you
Maggie never really lets her guard down, does she?
to give someone bad news in a way that will not upset them too much
I get asked out on dates quite often, but I always try to let the guy down gently.
to allow the air to escape from something so that it loses its shape and becomes flat
Someone’s let my tyres down!
to make a piece of clothing longer by unfolding a folded edge
take up
You let someone do something
Her boss lets her work from home
let someone to do something
Let is not used in the passive
You allow someone to do something
Her boss allows her to work from home
Something is allowed
Working from home is allowed
Allow is often used in the passive
Something  is permitted
Working from home is permitted
Someone is permitted to do something
Employees are permitted to work from home
Permit is usually used in the passive
